title: 109_hr2928
content: The Act is titled the "Compassionate Assistance for Rape Emergencies Act" and includes findings related to the act. The Congress finds that 25,000 to 32,000 women become pregnant each year due to rape or incest, with 22,000 pregnancies preventable with timely access to emergency contraception. A study found that 50% of these pregnancies end in abortion. Many hospitals do not routinely provide emergency contraception to sexual assault survivors, increasing the risk of pregnancy to 4.7% in unprotected survivors. Emergency contraception is safe and effective in preventing unintended pregnancy, with the FDA stating it can reduce the risk by up to 95% if taken within 24 hours. Medical research shows that administering emergency contraception sooner increases the likelihood of preventing pregnancy. Various medical associations support wider availability of emergency contraceptive pills. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend offering emergency contraception to female patients after sexual assault as standard care. Data shows that emergency contraception has prevented thousands of abortions and contributed to a decrease in total abortions. It is crucial for all hospitals providing emergency medical treatment to offer emergency contraception to sexually assaulted women. Emergency contraception should be offered to sexually assaulted women to prevent unintended pregnancies. Survivors of sexual assault should be provided with emergency contraceptives by hospitals at no cost. Federal funds cannot be given to hospitals under health-related programs unless they meet conditions for providing emergency contraception to sexual assault victims. This includes offering accurate information about emergency contraception promptly. Emergency contraception, approved by the FDA, is a safe and effective way to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. It does not cause abortion or interrupt an established pregnancy. Hospitals must offer and provide emergency contraception promptly upon request in clear and concise language. Hospitals must offer and provide emergency contraception promptly upon request in clear and concise language. The services are not denied due to financial constraints. The term "emergency contraception" refers to FDA-approved drugs or devices used postcoitally. The term "hospital" is defined as per the Social Security Act, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. "Sexual assault" is defined as non-consensual coitus. This section becomes effective after 180 days from the enactment of the Act, with the Secretary required to publish criteria for implementation 30 days prior to that.
